issues.text: whether on the materials on record the Courts below were right in presuming a lost grant in favour of the defendants

anchor.surface_text: The substantial question that arises for our decision is whether on the materials on record the Courts below were right in presuming a lost grant in favour of the defendants.

issues.text: whether in this situation a presumption of lost grant could be made

anchor.surface_text: The position thus is that there is no proof that the respondents set up any adverse title prior to 1931, much less that the plaintiff had knowledge of the same. We are therefore left with a bare finding that the defendants and their predecessors in title had been in possession for a long period without payment of rent but here again, there is no finding as to the precise length of time during which they held possession. The question is whether in this situation a presumption of lost grant could be made.

issues.text: whether on the facts found a lost grant could be presumed in favour of the defendants

anchor.surface_text: In the light of these principles, it has now to be seen whether on the facts found a lost grant could be presumed in favour of the defendants. The finding is, as already stated, that they were in possession without payment of rent for a considerable length of time, but it has not been established precisely for how long.

issues.text: whether the suits were within time under article 131 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below have held that the suits were within time under article 131 of the Limitation Act, as the final settlement of records was published on 16-6-1931, and the present suits were filed within 12 years thereof for establishing the right of the institution to assessment of rent.

issues.text: whether the title of the Asthal had become extinguished by adverse possession for long over the statutory period

anchor.surface_text: the contention that is now pressed before us is that in the view that there was no rent-free grant in favour of the predecessors of the defendants they were all trespassers, and that the title of the Asthal had become extinguished by adverse possession for long over the statutory period.

issues.text: whether a presumption of lost grant could be founded on the entry in the record of rights

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents relied strongly on the record of rights made in 1931 with reference to the suit lands as supporting his contention. The entry in question describes the lands as Bhog Dakhal Sutre Niskar, and has been translated as without rent by virtue of possession and enjoyment.

issues.text: whether the grant was one which could have legally been made by the Mahant

anchor.surface_text: But before raising such a presumption, it must be established that the grant was one which could have legally been made by him. It is well settled that it is beyond the powers of a manager of a religious institution to grant perpetual lease binding the institution for all times to a fixed rent, unless there is a compelling necessity or benefit therefor.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial question that arises for our decision is whether on the materials on record the Courts below were right in presuming a lost grant in favour of the defendants.

arguments.claim: No proof respondents set up adverse title or plaintiff knowledge pre-1931

anchor.surface_text: No attempt was made before us on behalf of the respondents to connect any of the documents with the lands held by them. ... The position thus is that there is no proof that the respondents set up any adverse title prior to 1931, much less that the plaintiff had knowledge of the same.

arguments.claim: Presumption of lost grant not applicable to bare long possession without payment of rent

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore left with a bare finding that the defendants and their predecessors in title had been in possession for a long period without payment of rent ... The circumstances and conditions under which a presumption of lost grant could be made are well settled.

arguments.claim: Lost grant presumption not juris et de jure, not if facts against or legal impediment

anchor.surface_text: When a person was found in possession and enjoyment of land for a considerable period of time under an assertion of title without challenge, Courts in England were inclined to ascribe a legal origin to such possession ... but that such grant had been lost. It was a presumption made for securing ancient and continued possession ...

arguments.claim: No lost grant presumption if no competent grantor or illegal grant

anchor.surface_text: There will likewise be no scope for this presumption, if there is no person capable of making a grant ... or if the grant would have been illegal and beyond the powers of the grantor.

arguments.claim: Suit lands assessed in 1793 Burdwan settlement as Mal, cannot be Lakheraj pre-settlement per Reg 8/1793 S36

anchor.surface_text: There was a permanent settlement of the zamindari of Burdwan in 1793, and it has been found by all the Courts that in that settlement the suit lands were included as part of the Mal ... Section 36 of the Regulation provides that the assessment is also to be fixed exclusive and independent of all existing lakheraje lands ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bare long possession without payment of rent insufficient; legal impediments including 1793 assessment excluding lakheraj, ultra vires Mahant grant, denial of grantor title, record entry merely non-payment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord-tenant relationship subsists; mokarrari title accepted; no lost grant or adverse possession extinguishing title

holdings.text: Assessed Mal lands in permanent settlement of 1793 cannot be held under pre-settlement lakheraj grant; no scope for lost grant presumption

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when it is shown that lands in an estate are assessed, it must follow that they could not have been held on the date of the permanent settlement as Lakheraj. It

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reg 8/1793 s36 fixes assessment exclusive of lakheraj; inconsistent with scheme of settlement to presume prior lakheraj on assessed lands

holdings.text: Presumption of lost grant cannot be founded on entry in record of rights

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that a presumption of lost grant cannot be founded on the entry in the record of rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 'Bhog Dakhal Sutre Niskar' per Rule 37 means non-paying possession, not rent-free grant; cannot outweigh 1793 assessment evidence

holdings.text: Defendants cannot presume lost grant from Maharaja or Asthal after denying their title

anchor.surface_text: But the defendants have in their written statements denied the title of both the Maharaja and the Asthal, and having failed in that plea, cannot fall back on a presumption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea of no title by possible grantors; cannot repudiate then rely on grant from them

holdings.text: No presumption of lost grant by Mahant as lakheraj or perpetual fixed rent grant beyond powers without compelling necessity or benefit

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that it is beyond the powers of a manager of a religious institution to grant perpetual lease binding the institution for all times to a fixed rent,

anchor.surface_text: That, in itself, is not sufficient to make their possession adverse. It was only in 1931 that the defendants could be said clearly to have asserted a hostile title,

holdings.text: Presumption of lost grant not juris et de jure; not raised if facts against or legal impediment exists

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances and conditions under which a presumption of lost grant could be made are well settled. When a person was found in possession and enjoyment of land for a

holdings.reasoning_summary: English and Indian precedents: for ancient possession without explanation; rebuttable; no if incompetent grantor, illegal grant, or facts contradict

anchor.surface_text: observed Farwell, J. in Attorney-General v. Simpson 1 . So also the presumption was number made if there was any legal impediment to the making of it.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumption of lost grant is not a presumption juris et de jure and courts are not bound to raise it if facts in evidence go against it; judge should not presume a grant whose non-existence he is convinced of
precedents.cited_holding: It cannot be the duty of a Judge to presume a grant of the non-existence of which he is convinced

precedents.citation: Raja Braja Sundar Deb v. Moni Behara and others 1 1951 S.C R. 431, 416

anchor.surface_text: That was held in Raja Braja Sundar Deb v. Moni Behara and others 1 . There will likewise be numberscope for this  1  1901 2 Ch. D. 671, 698.  2  1951 S.C R. 431, 416.

precedents.case_name: Raja Braja Sundar Deb v Moni Behara
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption of lost grant cannot be made if there is no person competent to be the recipient of such a grant, as where the right is claimed by a fluctuating body of persons

anchor.surface_text: Vide Barker v. Richardson 1  and The Rochdale Canal Company v. Radcliffe 1 . In the light of these principles, it has number to be seen whether on the facts found a lost grant companyld be presumed in favour of the defendants.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumption of lost grant not made if the grant would have been illegal and beyond the powers of the grantor

precedents.citation: The Rochdale Canal Company v. Radcliffe 1 1852 18 Q. B. 287

anchor.surface_text: Vide Barker v. Richardson 1  and The Rochdale Canal Company v. Radcliffe 1 . In the light of these principles, it has number to be seen whether on the facts found a lost grant companyld be presumed in favour of the defendants.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumption of lost grant not made if the grant would have been illegal and beyond the powers of the grantor

precedents.citation: Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreenath Devasikamony 1 1917 L.R. 44 I.A. 147

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that it is beyond the powers of a manager of a religious institution to grant perpetual lease binding the institution for all times to a fixed rent, unless there is a companypelling necessity or benefit therefor. Vide Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreenath Devasikamony 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: beyond the powers of a manager of a religious institution to grant perpetual lease binding the institution for all times to a fixed rent unless compelling necessity or benefit

anchor.surface_text: In Barker v. Richardson 2  , an easement was claimed both on the ground of prescription and presumption of a lost grant by a rector. In negativing this claim, Abbot, C. J. observed that a grant companyld number be presumed, because the rector had numberright to bind his successor by it, and it would therefore be invalid.

precedents.cited_proposition: a grant could not be presumed because the rector had no right to bind his successor by it, and it would therefore be invalid
precedents.cited_holding: a grant could not be presumed, because the rector had no right to bind his successor by it, and it would therefore be invalid

precedents.citation: The Rochdale Canal Company Radcliffe 1 1852 18 Q.B. 287

anchor.surface_text: In The Rochdale Canal Company Radcliffe 1  where the Court was asked to presume that a companypany had made a grant of its surplus waters for use by the Duke of Bridgewater, Lord Campbell, C. J. observed that if they had made a grant of the water in the terms of this plea, such a grant would have been ultra vires and bad, and on that ground, he refused to raise the presumption.

precedents.cited_proposition: refused to raise presumption of lost grant because such a grant would have been ultra vires and bad
precedents.cited_holding: if they had made a grant of the water in the terms of this plea, such a grant would have been ultra vires and bad
